✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Original, several possible solutions, complex but not too hard :)
Perhaps the banner art could be many many roulette wheels... that might help convey the point.

Why not be a bit kinder to Burt.
Perhaps he's not dumb at all... just suspicious of formulas and prefers to learn by doing actual experiments

I wrote code using
Random r = new Random() 
and 
int rInt = r.Next(0, 38)
...convinced that sometimes my answers would match your answers and sometimes not because... you know...randomness.
(Randomness should mean that sometimes a coin flipped 100 times will land on heads way more than 50.)

But it matched every time!!!

Please explain the magic in the universe.
I think it's purely a math problem.

Nice problem, but wouldn't it be better in medium difficulty? You definitely need to know what you are doing when computing the recursive formula for the probability

Also, how about adding a recursivity tag?

I know the simulation way but there is always a nonzero chance of failing.

Hey ! 
Didn't approved because it'd fit in a medium difficulty rather than an easy one 
(you know, like retaining waters :) )
Anyways, it's fun to do, but could be hard for some people because of m relation with recursively m-1 etc... !
(If the difficulty changes, i'll approve it :) ).
Was fun to do anyways !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: interesting problem!
cost me several papers to figure out the relationship between m and (m-1, m-2, ..., 1).
I use a recursive way to calculate each exact m difference numbers, timeout for too deep. managed to memoize manually and passed.

feeling not so easy...
unsuccessful with a mental solution,  finally grab a paper and pen to try

if I knew Inclusion–exclusion principle better (only learnt the n=3 case before), it would be much easier to find the solution.

The Monte Carlo Simulation is indeed a good way to avoid thinking. :)
Hmmm, well you don't have to do anything with math or recursion to solve it.  Just randomly generate a bunch of spins and print out the percentage.
It doesn't need recursion.  How did you use recursion?
That can be solved with a program without knowing any math, imagine that!

Heh heh, just the law of large numbers doing its thing.  I really wanted to add a decimal point to the solutions, but even making my code around 10x faster than the solution here it couldn't stabilize in such a short time.
Nice! You are better at math than Burt is.
Thinking about it, you could add a Monte-Carlo algorithm (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_algorithm) tag if possible. This way, you'd get a clue that simulation is a valid approach.
I kind of like it that everyone is solving it in ways I didn't expect.  I would hate for a tag to discourage creativity.
You're right, i've looked about you're solution ( I didn't knew what were math.comb() for so i've looked for it) and it's an interesting way.

looks like my comment is misleading ;)
please let me clarify that recursion is not a necessary, it's just personal preference
